answer_html: On an exam, either answer, \((10,\infty)\) or \([10,\infty)\), would be acceptable.)
answer_latex:
On an exam, either
answer, $(10,\infty)$ or $[10,\infty)$, would be acceptable.)
hints_html:
First, note that this problem is not asking for the interval(s) where \(N(t)\) is decreasing, but rather where its derivative \(N'(t)\) is decreasing.

When a differentiable function is decreasing, what can you say about its first derivative?
hints_latex:
When a differentiable function is decreasing, what can you say about its
first derivative?
hints_raw:
First, note that this problem is ''not'' asking for the interval(s) where <math>N(t)</math> is decreasing, but rather where its ''derivative'' <math>N'(t)</math> is decreasing.
When a differentiable function is decreasing, what can you say about its first derivative?
question: 1 (d)
sols_html:
As long as \(N''(t)\) is negative, \(N'(t)\) is decreasing. Differentiating \(N(t),\)

\[\begin{aligned} N'(t) = 60t-3t^2\end{aligned}\]

Differentiating again,

\[\begin{aligned} N''(t) = 60-6t.\end{aligned}\]

This is negative whenever \(6t>60,\) i.e. \(t>10.\) We can conclude that \(N'(t)\) is decreasing for all \(t>10.\)

(Furthermore, \(N'(t)\) is continuous, we also know that it is increasing on the closed interval, \([10,\infty)\). On an exam, either answer, \((10,\infty)\) or \([10,\infty)\), would be acceptable.)
sols_latex:
As long as $N''(t)$ is negative, $N'(t)$ is decreasing. Differentiating
$N(t),$

\begin{align*}
N'(t) = 60t-3t^2
\end{align*} Differentiating again,

\begin{align*}
N''(t) = 60-6t.
\end{align*} This is negative whenever $6t>60,$ i.e. $t>10.$ We
can conclude that $N'(t)$ is decreasing for all $t>10.$

\emph{(Furthermore, $N'(t)$ is continuous, we also know that it is
increasing on the closed interval, $[10,\infty)$. On an exam, either
answer, $(10,\infty)$ or $[10,\infty)$, would be acceptable.)}

</math> 
This is negative whenever <math>6t>60,</math> i.e. <math>t>10.</math>  We can conclude that <math>N'(t)</math> is decreasing for all <math>t>10.</math>

''(Furthermore, <math>N'(t) </math> is continuous, we also know that it is increasing on the closed interval, <math>[10,\infty)</math>.  On an exam, either answer, <math>(10,\infty)</math> or <math>[10,\infty)</math>, would be acceptable.)''
statement_html:
A drug that stimulates reproduction is introduced into a colony of bacteria. After t minutes, the number of bacteria is given approximately by

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}N(t)=1000+30t^2-t^3,\quad{}t\geq{0}\end{aligned}\]

When is the rate of growth \(\displaystyle {}N'(t)\) decreasing?
statement_raw:
A drug that stimulates reproduction is introduced into a colony of bacteria.  After t minutes, the number of bacteria is given approximately by

:<math>
\displaystyle{}N(t)=1000+30t^2-t^3,\quad{}t\geq{0}
</math>

When is the rate of growth <math>\displaystyle{}N'(t)</math> decreasing?
